description: From Middle English knoble; equivalent to knob +‎ -le.

examples: […]  I stared down into the chasm of this baby’s mouth, where the little pink knobble at the back of his throat was wiggling with the wind of his howl.

verbs.description: knobble (third-person singular simple present knobbles, present participle knobbling, simple past and past participle knobbled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a knobbly surface to.
(transitive, metallurgy) To produce wrought iron by treating (semirefined puddled iron) on a hearth before shingling.
